messages.text: Replacing the default sysimage is just a bad idea in general. Better to have a local sysimage and replace your `julia` command with an alias that loads julia with the custom sysimage.

elements.text: Replacing the default sysimage is just a bad idea in general. Better to have a local sysimage and replace your
julia
command with an alias that loads julia with the custom sysimage.

messages.text: Ive been trying to clear out stuff because for some reason if I just launch vscode on my local machine (mac os) and connect it with the VSCode Remote extension to my dev machine (Fedora 32) and have nothing open and no other extensions enabled, top on the dev machine shows bursts of 10-20% cpu usage every few seconds on a .vscode-server/bin process.  Im pretty sure this didn't used to happen but Im wondering if other people see this.  Blowing away every setting I can find doesnt help.  I can't see anything in any logs to indicate that it is actually doing anything.

elements.text: Ive been trying to clear out stuff because for some reason if I just launch vscode on my local machine (mac os) and connect it with the VSCode Remote extension to my dev machine (Fedora 32) and have nothing open and no other extensions enabled, top on the dev machine shows bursts of 10-20% cpu usage every few seconds on a .vscode-server/bin process.  Im pretty sure this didn't used to happen but Im wondering if other people see this.  Blowing away every setting I can find doesnt help.  I can't see anything in any logs to indicate that it is actually doing anything.

messages.text: Ive also tried having the client machine be a different ubuntu box and I get the same result.

elements.text: Ive also tried having the client machine be a different ubuntu box and I get the same result.

messages.text:
I’ve had trouble with remote ssh julia paths before. I edited the main remote settings.json to include environment paths and executable path. The main settings.json can be a bit tricky to find. I believe it should be in ~/.vscode-server/data/Machine. If not, through vs code, head to remote ssh settings, toggle to remote machine settings and find ‘Remote: Extension kind’, underwhich there should be an option to edit the remote settings.json.

Presumably it’s finding your old environment and setting that as the default environment. I think you can change this in the remote settings.json. You can also change for a particular directory by editing the /directory/.vscode/settings.json and including the desired environment path.

I’m not sure why the cpu bursts. I remember having his when the language server was indexing on start up.

elements.text:
I’ve had trouble with remote ssh julia paths before. I edited the main remote settings.json to include environment paths and executable path. The main settings.json can be a bit tricky to find. I believe it should be in ~/.vscode-server/data/Machine. If not, through vs code, head to remote ssh settings, toggle to remote machine settings and find ‘Remote: Extension kind’, underwhich there should be an option to edit the remote settings.json.

Presumably it’s finding your old environment and setting that as the default environment. I think you can change this in the remote settings.json. You can also change for a particular directory by editing the /directory/.vscode/settings.json and including the desired environment path.

I’m not sure why the cpu bursts. I remember having his when the language server was indexing on start up.
